sec.title: Abstract
sec.p: In this study, four new Brazilian species are described for the genus AdelosgryllusMesa & Zefa, 2004 , occurring in Minas Gerais , Tocantins and Pará states. Three of these species were found in caves and one was found in endogenous habitats, representing the first record of species form this genus for such habitats. The morphology of the phallic complex was used as the main criterion for distinguishing the new species, the copulatory papilla was also described for one of the new species. Finally, we bring a brief discussion about the ecology, distribution, and conservation of these species.
Key words: Ensifera; Crickets; Taxonomic knowledge
Resumo

Neste estudo são descritas quatro novas espécies brasileiras para o gênero AdelosgryllusMesa & Zefa, 2004 , ocorrentes nos estados de Minas Gerais , Tocantins e Pará . Três destas distribuídas em cavernas e uma em habitats endógenos, representando o primeiro registro de espécies deste gênero para este tipo de habitat. A morfologia do complexo fálico foi utilizada como principal critério para diferenciação das novas espécies, e também descrevemos a papila copulatória para uma das novas espécies. Por fim, trazemos uma breve discussão sobre a ecologia, distribuição e conservação destas espécies.
Palavras-chave: Ensifera, Grilos, Conhecimento Taxonômico

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Thus, in the present study, we describe four new species for the genus AdelosgryllusMesa & Zefa, 2004 , of which three occur in caves and the fourth is associated with endogenous habitats (SSH - Shallow subterranean habitats), representing the first record of species from the genus in such habitats. Additionally, we discuss aspects of the ecology, distribution and conservation of the new species.

sec.title: Material and Methods
sec.p: Study area

The second species was collected on Pará state , municipality of Curionópolis, in SL-94, SL-109 and SL-110 caves (
, black star) with additional specimens observed in SL-79, SL-82 and SL-121 caves, all inserted in the ferruginous region of Carajás. The predominant biome in the region is the Amazon Forest (
Olson et al. , 2001
).

The third and fourth species were collected in Minas Gerais state , being one of them observed in Conceição do Mato Dentro municipality, in Resgate cave (
, water-green star). This cave is inserted in the Espinhaço Supergroup and the main biome is the Atlantic Forest. The fourth species was found in the Pains municipality, and it is associated to endogenous habitats. Specimens were sampled through subterranean traps installed near one cave (
, purple star). The area is inserted within the Bambuí carbonate group, and represents an ecotonal area between the Cerrado (Brazilian Savannah) and the Atlantic Forest domains.
Collection and examination

The specimens were collected by active searching inside the caves, except for the endogenous species found in Pains municipality, which was sampled with subterranean traps with a solution of 4% formalin as described by Rendoš (2012) . Immediately after collection, the specimens were fixed in an aqueous solution of 70% ethanol. In the laboratory, the phallic sclerites and copulatory papilla were dissected. After dissection, the phallic complex was treated with an aqueous solution of potassium hydroxide ( KOH ) at a concentration of 10% for 10 minutes, to remove membranous and muscular tissues. The phallic sclerites and copulatory papilla of each specimen were stored in vials containing 70% aqueous solution of ethanol with the other parts of the specimen. For measurements and photographs an Axion Zoom V16 (ZEISS) stereomicroscope were utilized.

The nomenclature used to describe the male phallic sclerites and copulatory papilla were based on Desutter (1987 , 1988 ), modified by Desutter-Grandcolas (2003) and the terminology used by Corrêa et al. , (2018).

Etymology. The specific epithet ferratilis refers to the presence of this species in iron caves.
Ecological Remarks

Specimens of Adelosgryllus ferratilis n. sp. were found in Curionópolis municipality, Pará state , Brazil . The caves where specimens were observed are located in an area regionally known as “Serra Leste”. This area presents several iron-ore caves, but also some quartzite caves. The species was observed in several caves in the area, especially those ferruginous. Such caves are usually small (few dozens of meters) and several cavities only comprises rock shelters, without aphotic areas. The main organic resources observed in those caves is the bat guano and vegetable organic debris, deposited by wind or water. Although the area was originally covered by a tropical rainforest (Amazon rainforest), it is currently highly impacted, by both the replacement of the forests by pastures and by mining activities. The populations of A. ferratilis n. sp. are usually small inside the caves, so that the species may use the caves only sporadically. However, since the external environments were not sampled, it is currently impossible to establish the actual distribution of this species (
).

Since the specimens of Adelosgryllus megapterus n. sp. were not collected by any of the authors of this study, there is no information regarding its habitat preferences. sec.title: Discussion
sec.p:
In this study, we observed a discoloration on specimens of A. ferratilis n. sp. and A. xambioa n. sp. when comparing the in vivo photos to the specimens fixed in ethanol 70%. This discoloration has already been mentioned for A. similis and A. cruscastaneus (
Corrêa et al. , 2018
)
and A. lucifugus (
Merlo et al. , 2021
)
. It is interesting to note that the specimens of A. endogeus n. sp. , which apparently retained the original coloration, were firstly fixed in formalin 4% (conservative solution used in the traps), and later in 70% ethanol, so that this fixative may have prevented discoloration; however, better investigations are needed in order to confirm or refute this.

From this study, it is possible to group the Adelosgryllus species
(based on male adults) into three distinct groups, taking into account the morphology of the phallic complex. The first group is formed by the species A. spurius , A. lucifugus , A. ferratilis n. sp. , A. xambioa n. sp. , and A. megapterus n. sp. , which present a quadrangularshaped phallic complex, highlighted mainly by the presence of a paramere 1 of pseudepiphallus C-shaped (Ps.P1), analogous to a “hook”, with the median pseudepiphalic lophy (Ps.m.l) claviform and thin. The second group is formed by the species A. parasimilis , A. similis , A. cruscastaneus and A. endogeus n. sp. , which present a vertically elongated phallic complex of rectangular shape, highlighted by the presence of parameres 1 and 2 forming a lenticular structure, with the median pseudepiphalic lophi (Ps.m.l) developed and extended. Finally, A. rubricephalus compose an isolated group, with a quadrangular-shaped phallic complex, highlighted mainly by the presence of the paramere 1 narrow in dorsal and ventral view, with the median pseudepiphalic lophy (Ps.m.l) slightly developed compared to the first two groups.

The female copulatory papilla is still unknown for most species of this genus, being only known to four species. In two of them ( A. rubricephalus and A. cruscastaneus ) it presents a square shape, while in the other two species ( A. lucifugus and A. megapterus n. sp. ) it presents a circular shape.

While describing the species A. rubricephalus , Mesa and Zefa (2004) detected the presence of a pair of well-developed hindwings in three females found in Iguaçu, Paraná state , Brazil . In addition, Corrêa (2017) also documented this morphology in a female collected in the Iguaçu National Park, Paraná state , Brazil . Until then, the presence of well-developed hindwings was unknown for adult males of this genus. However, in this study, we observed a male of the species A. megapterus n. sp. with such morphology. Although still speculative, these well-developed wings occurring in some individuals of certain species may eventually contribute to their dispersal. However, future studies should be developed on this topic to confirm or refute this hypothesis.

It is important to highlight that, in recent years, new localities have been recorded for the genus Adelosgryllus (https://www.inaturalist.org/observations?taxon_id=765973) in Brazil ( Acre , Mato Grosso , Minas Gerais , Rio de Janeiro and Paraná states), Argentina ( Misiones , Chaco and González Moreno provinces) and Bolivia (Sara province), from records shared on the citizen science platform Inaturalist (iNaturalist, 2022). It should be noted that in some of these records it is possible to observe specimens with well-developed hindwings, which reinforces the eventual dispersive function of these structures, especially when considering the wide geographic distribution that these small crickets may present.

The new species of AdelosgryllusMesa & Zefa, 2004 described in this work, from four different regions of the Brazil , reveal the great potential for the discovery of new species of this genus, which is still little known. Furthermore, the new species found in interstitial habitats ( A. endogeus n. sp. )
reveals the diversity of habitats capable of being used by these organisms. Finally, the importance of preserving caves is highlighted, since three of the species herein described were found in such environments. It is crucial to preserve the habitats of these species, so that future studies can be carried out, in order to better understand aspects of the ecology and distribution of this species, as well as its relationships with the several subterranean habitats where they occur.
